This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
The last time we saw Bob Newhart was at the Emmy Awards, where he faced almost certain death at the hands of host Conan O'Brien.
(Soundbite of "58th Annual Primetime Emmy Awards")
Mr. CONAN O'BRIEN (Comedian): Tonight I have placed beloved TV icon Bob Newhart...
(Soundbite of laughter and applause)
Mr. O'BRIEN: ...in an airtight container with exactly three hours worth of air.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, we're happy to report that Mr. Newhart made it.
And after all of his success on television, in movies, on records and in standup comedy, his first book is just out.
It's called I Shouldn't Even Be Doing This!: And Other Things That Strike Me as Funny.
Not a memoir exactly, it's his story of a kid from Chicago who turned a trademark stammer and one-sided telephone conversations into a lifetime of laughter.
MR.
NEWHART: You sure are, Neal.
Italy's crime rate remains one of the lowest in Europe, but mounting fear and unease over the rapidly growing wave of immigrants have created a mood of xenophobia.
However, there's at least one positive effect for the Roma.
It has attracted the attention of the European Union, which has long ignored the plight of the largest, poorest and least-known minority on the continent.
Sylvia Poggioli, NPR News, Rome.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton spelled out the political stakes in Indiana today.
Obama said it could be the tie-breaker of the Democratic race, and Clinton said the state could pick the next president.
Now some things you might not know about Indiana, it is called the crossroads of America.
It has more interstate highways per square mile than any other state.
NPR's David Schaper surveyed the Indiana landscape in advance of the May 6th primary.
Indiana is a farm state, right?
Lots of corn, soy beans, livestock, well, yes.
But, agriculture is not the driving force of the state's economy.
If you want to characterize Indiana, relative to the nation, we are a manufacturing state, not a farm state.
That's Don Coffin, economics professor at Indiana University Northwest, in Gary, standing in the shadow of the massive U.S.
steel plant.
This is, sort of, the epicenter really of what has been the core of the northwest Indiana economy.
Northwest Indiana still produces tons of steel, more tons today, in fact, than ever before.
But the mills do it with fewer workers.
About 20,000 compared to a peak of 100,000 in the late 1960s, in the Lake Michigan shoreline cities of Gary, Hammond, Whiting and East Chicago.
The lake front cities have been extremely hard hit.
They've been in decline for 30 or 40 years, across - just all across the lake front.
This voting block has lost about 40 percent of its population since 1970, Coffin says.
But it still matters to Democrats which is why Senator Clinton is meeting with steel workers in Gary tonight.
Something else you might not have known?
Indiana is the number two auto making state historically, second only to neighboring Michigan.
This state is dotted with factory towns such as Kokomo and Anderson, where Obama is campaigning today.
These and others like Fort Wayne, Muncie and South Bend have been bleeding jobs for a generation.
People are worried, people are struggling, they really are.
Two-income households - it doesn't really matter at this point.
Gina Morris of Indianapolis.
She works for a Medicaid provider.
I know some people lost their jobs.
It's hard to find a job.
One thing everyone knows about Indiana, it's a red state, right?
Right in presidential elections, at least.
A Democrat has carried the state just once in the last 50 years.
But Indiana often elects Democratic governors 20 - years straight up until 2004 - and Democratic Senator Evan Bayh won his last re-election with nearly two thirds of the vote.
Democrats control the Indiana House and now hold five of the state's nine seats in Congress.
Why doesn't that translate to presidential candidates?
The Democratic party in Indiana is a conservative party, really.
Margaret Ferguson teaches political science at Indiana University-Purdue University, Indianapolis.
But being a Democrat in Indiana is not the same thing as being a Democrat in New York or Vermont.
Right now, all of that would seem to benefit Senator Clinton who has done best in states with lots of older, white blue-collar voters who don't live in major metropolitan areas.
But remember, Indiana is also next door to Senator Obama's home state.
In fact, his home on Chicago South Side is just a couple of miles from the Indiana state line.
Professor Ferguson.
People who live up there get almost all their news from Chicago, their television, they're in that market.
Obama can also count on African-American voters in Gary and Indianapolis.
It's going to be off the hook here on Election Day.
Amos Brown hosts an afternoon talk show on Indianapolis radio station WTLC.
When I hit the air at one o'clock and start talking about the presidential race, the phones light up like a Christmas tree.
Brown says his audience and voters across the state are enjoying their rare moment in the national political spotlight.
Voter registration is up 160,000 for this primary, and turnout could set a record.
The latest Indiana polls show the Clinton-Obama race is a statistical dead heat.
David Schaper, NPR News, Indianapolis.
Quiz question, not so trivial: Will she or won't she?
NPR's senior news analyst, Daniel Schorr.
The she, you guessed it, is Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
She is the subject of endless speculation about whether she will drop out of the presidential race considering that she's behind Senator Barack Obama in the delegate count.
It doesn't help that the public foresees Obama as a stronger candidate against Senator John McCain, according to the polls.
But in a volatile situation, that may not be decisive.
It wasn't for nothing that Senator Clinton's husband dubbed himself the Comeback Kid, faced with the possibility of overwhelming defeat in the 1992 New Hampshire primary.
After the revelation of his relationship with Jennifer Flowers, he lost by just under nine points.
Under the circumstances, a victory.
So now, the great game of doing better than expected is being played out in the run-up to the Pennsylvania primary.
Obama supporters seemed delighted to concede Senator Clinton a big lead.
That way, if she wins the primary by anything less than double digits, they can claim victory over expectations.
It will be huge.
Basically AT&T already has a very large local phone business in the Midwest, the South and the West.
Now it is adding a lot of Southeast.
It will have 70 million local customers, 10 million broadband customers.
It will be a big player in Internet services, business services, long-distance and also in wireless.
AT&T already had a majority share of Cingular.
Now it is acquiring BellSouth, it's going to own the whole thing.
The two companies have a total of 316,000 employees, so it is going to be huge.
Bigger than its next biggest competitor, which is Verizon.
Now, AT&T was once the nation's dominant phone company and then the government came in, forced it to break up, creating these smaller businesses, including BellSouth.
Are we seeing the old Ma Bell coming back to life again with this deal?
Well, yes and no. You're right.
AT&T was split into smaller companies, and then there have been a number of mergers which have reduced the players in the field.
The company that is now known as AT&T is not exactly the same company that existed before.
The company that now calls itself AT&T is really the former SBC, which was the baby Bell based in San Antonio.
SBC bought AT&T last year and took its name.
The bottom line though is that this new AT&T like the old one is a very big and powerful company.
A lot of consumers groups are already saying it is too big and that all this merging is going to be bad for competition.
What do the two companies have to say about that issue of competition?
Well, they say this will allow them to be bigger and stronger and serve customers better.
They say they'll save about $2 billion a year by combining operations.
They also say these companies serve different geographic areas, so the merger isn't going to hurt competition.
Of course the federal government is going to have to weigh in on that as it does with all big mergers.
